case_vignette: A 50-year-old African American male with past medical history of hypertension and hypertension presents for evaluation of light spots on his legs that he initially noticed one year ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy, but he is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. He has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have light spots on my legs that have been increasing in number.
How long have you been noticing these light spots?
I initially noticed the light spots on my legs one year ago.
Do these spots itch, hurt, or cause any discomfort?
No, the spots are not painful or itchy.
Do you have a personal or family history of skin conditions such as psoriasis, eczema, or any other immune-related disorders?
I do not have any personal or family history of skin conditions or immune-related disorders.
Have you been exposed to any new skincare products, detergents, or chemicals that might have triggered this skin reaction?
No, I have not been exposed to any new skincare products, detergents, or chemicals.
Have you had any recent illnesses or infections, or are you currently taking any medications?
I have a medical history of hypertension and I take medication for it, but I haven't had any recent illnesses or infections.
Does anyone in your family have similar skin issues or vitiligo?
No, no one in my family has similar skin issues or vitiligo.
Have the spots changed in texture or color over time? Also, do they have any borders or are they uniformly spread?
The spots have not significantly grown in size or changed in texture, and they are ovoid shaped and scattered on my legs.
**Final Diagnosis:** Idiopathic Guttate Hypomelanosis
